title: Beavers could be reintroduced into the wild by government for first time in 500 years, environment minister Zac Goldsmith suggests
text:
Beavers could be reintroduced into the wild for the first time in half a century, Zac Goldsmith has suggested.

The animals were made almost extinct in Europe some centuries ago after being hunted for their fur and an oil they produce which was a main component of cosmetics.

The body parts of a single beaver were worth the equivalent of a year's salary in England, so those who hunted them could easily double their annual pay. This caused their population to steeply decline.

They are now having a "rewilding" resurgence across the continent, and in some parts of America, as they have been found to reduce flooding and droughts by building dams, as well as tidying willow trees next to waterways so sunlight can hit the streams and they remain clean.

In areas where beavers have been found, conservationists say, amphibian and fish populations have increased, and the water has been cleaner and healthier.

It is currently illegal to release beavers into the wild, because of the changes they can make to the environment. The issue has been hotly contested by some farmers because of the possibility of the animals causing floods to potato and carrot farms near streams.

Environmentalists argue that this can be mitigated; in Bavaria where they have reintroduced beavers, the government relocates creatures which are causing issues for farmers.
